catalogue_raissonne: Seth Eastman: A Portfolio of North American Indians 10
creditline: Gift of the W. Duncan and Nivin MacMillan Foundation
inscription:
Title and Inscription

URC, above image, in brown ink and pencil: [Pl. 29]; lower center, below image, in pencil and brown ink: [FEMALE (written in pencil) / DACOTAHS / Mode of sitting]
provenance: James J. Hill (St. Paul, 1838-1916); his estate; James Jerome Hill Reference Library St. Paul (by 1921-1994; sold October, to MacMillan); W. Duncan MacMillan, Wayzata (1994-d. 2006); the W. Duncan and Nivin MacMillan Foundation (2006-2014; given to MIA)
signed: LL, below image, in brown ink: [S. Eastman U.S. Army Del.t]
text:
"Dacotahs Mode of Sitting" shows front and back views of the same pose. This sepia drawing also documents the variety of imported cloth available to Native people. Communities participated in a dynamic exchange of goods with cultures far and wide, and cotton and wool became increasingly important as hides became scarce.

This drawing is one of 35 works on paper by Seth Eastman in Mia’s collection. It was the basis for an illustration in Henry Rowe Schoolcraft’s massive "Historical and Statistical Information Respecting the History, Condition, and Prospects of the Indian Tribes of the United States" (Philadelphia: Lippincott, Grambo & Co., 1851-57).
title: Dacotahs Mode of Sitting
